results.title: Firelight = Clair-Obscure
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, ONF | NFB and Paul Bochner
results.brief_description: A highly personal and impressionistic piece of work, Firelight explores time. This animated film has long dissolves and pastel shades which reflect its ephemeral nature, its steady progression and the constancy of its cycles. It is a gentle film that sets the mind adrift. Film without words. Music by Eldon Rathburn.

results.title: Fire: what makes it burn?
results.creator_credit: James Bishop and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Uses simple laboratory demonstrations to show the factors involved in combustion, and that different materials require various degrees of heat for ignition. Emphasises the dangers of fire and illustrates safety measures.

results.title: Fire: two ways out
results.brief_description: Homes can burn very rapidly. Victims generally suffocate and become unconscious before the fire actually reaches them. It is important to know how to escape if a fire threatens your home. Two escape routes must be planned in advance in case one is blocked by flames.

results.title: Fire: not in my house
results.brief_description: The aim of the film is to motivate the viewer to clean up fire hazards in their home. Home fires can be more immediately damaging than ecological pollution. Several people are spectators at a home fire; on their return home, they recognise fire hazards in their own environment, and quickly take steps to eliminate the possibility of fires in their homes.

results.title: Fire: friend or foe
results.brief_description: Various fire risks and precautions, and fire-fighting techniques. After indicating the immense cost to the community involved in fires, the film shows the work of the Survey Department of the Fire and Accident Underwriters’ Association, and the Commonwealth Expeprimental Building Station in reducing fire hazards. Two types of automatic alarm are shown in action and the work of the fire brigades is described.

results.title: Fire, Water, Earth
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: A report on the environmental damage that the Western Mining Corporation is causing to the Arabunna people by the siphoning of 42 million litres of water a day from the Great Artesian Basin. The world’s largest uranium mine is located at Roxby Downs in South Australia. It is owned by multinational mining corporation WMC and is built on Arabunna and Kokotha land. This story follows the nuclear trail from an occupation of a WMC borefield by Arabunna elder Kevin Buzzacott and his supporters to a daring mission by videoactivists into the heart of WMC headquarters in Melbourne, surprising the boss himself.Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Fire without smoke
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Dept of Scientific and Industrial Research
results.brief_description: Traces the development of a simple but effective device for abolishing the industrial smoke menace. In wartime the black smoke trails from ships’ funnels indicated the position of convoys. Experiments carried out on board ship and at the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research’s Fuel Resesarch Station resulted in a new boiler door fitment which minimised the danger. Redesigned to suit industrial boilers, the smoke eliminator door also saves a considerable quantity of fuel.

results.title: Fire weather
results.creator_credit: Media World and Victoria. Country Fire Authority
results.brief_description: This video looks at the effects of weather on bushfire behaviour. Weather factors discussed are temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric stability, air mass, pressure systems and fronts. Focusing mainly on Victoria, it concentrates on the implications for firefighters. Knowledge of these weather factors will enable the fire fighter to predict fire behaviour.

results.title: Fire vs fire
results.brief_description: A fire control training film, based on a conference held to discuss burning out and backfiring as techniques of controlling forest fires. The indirect attack is backfiring (backburning) toward the main fire from a distance. Burning out necessitates working in close and burning toward the fire.

results.title: Fire threat
results.brief_description: A young mum recounts her stress at her partner deciding to stay in Warburton while she and her young daughter go to her mum’s house. She speaks about her ‘uni days’ and the change in priorities now that she is a mum.
